dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAHAM DALTON, twenty-nine, drives his '69 Cutlass while a cigarette. One could describe his appearance as punk/ar but neither would do him justice. He is a man of obvious  intelligence, and his face is amiable. There is only one on his keyring, and it is in the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) Garbage. I started thinking about  what happens to all the garbage.  I mean, where do we put all of  it, we have to run out of places  to put it eventually, don't we?  This happened to me before when  that barge with all the garbage  was stranded and nobody would take  it? Remember that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANN BISHOP MILLANEY, twenty-six, sits opposite her therap She is an extremely attractive woman, dressed in a mature style. There is a wedding ring on her left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember. What do you do  when these moods overtake you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I mean, nothing. I try  not to do anything that will  produce garbage, so obviously we're  talking about eating and basic  stuff like that. Did you know that  the average person produces three  pounds of garbage a day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think that's a lot of  garbage? I'd really like to know  where it's all going to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what triggered  this concern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this weekend John was taking  out the garbage, and he kept  spilling things out of the  container, and I started imagining  a container that grew garbage,  like it just kept filling up and  overflowing all by itself, and  how could you stop that if it  started happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann, do you see a pattern here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, last week we talked about  your obsession with the families  of airline fatalities, and now  we're talking about your concern  over the garbage problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you think about it, I think  you'll see that the object of your  obsession is invariably something  negative that you couldn't possibly  have any control over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, do you think many people  run around thinking about how happy  they feel and how great things  are? I mean, maybe they do, but  I doubt those people are in  therapy. Besides, being happy isn't  all that great. My figure is always  at its best when I'm depressed.  The last time I was really happy  I put on twenty-five pounds. I  thought John was going to have  a stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) It's true, I'm telling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN MILLANEY, twenty-nine, sits at his desk talking on t telephone. He is dressed very well, sporting real suspend with his striped pinpoint oxford shirt and cotton suit. H fingers the wedding ring on his left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as you've got a ring on  your finger, you start getting  serious attention from the opposite  gender. Seriously, I wish I had  Super Bowl seats for every time  I had some filly just come up  and start talking to me without  the slightest provocation. That  never happened before I got  married. Shit, if I'd known that,  I'd have gone out and bought me  a ring when I was eighteen and  saved myself a lot of time and  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I gotta be someplace. (quickly) Look, racquetball Thursday? You're  the coolest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John presses the intercom button while putting on his jac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Janet, re-schedule Kirkland.  Tell him to come in Friday at 1:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over, to Ann)  Are you still keeping these  thoughts from John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John brushes his teeth and combs his hair very carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over, to Ann) Are you afraid of his reaction?  Of his finding you silly for  thinking of such things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) No. I don't know. I haven't told  him about the garbage thing because  I'm pissed off at him right now.  He's letting some old college buddy  stay at our house for a couple  of days, and he didn't even ask  me about it. I mean, I would've  said yes, I just wish he would've  asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What upsets you about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm upset because I can't  really justify being upset, I mean,  it's his house, really, he pays  the mortgage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he asked you to quit your job,  and you do have housework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This unexpected visit  notwithstanding, how are things  with John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Fine, I guess. Except right now  I m going through this where I  don't want him to touch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CYNTHIA BISHOP, Ann's SISTER, opens her door to reveal th freshly coifed John Millaney. They kiss passionately and to disrobe. Cynthia bears a slight resemblance to Ann, bu is not as overtly attractive. She does, however, have a d carnal appeal and air of confidence that Ann lacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) When did you begin having this feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) About a week ago. I don't know  what brought it on, I just started  feeling like I didn't want him  to touch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over, to Ann) Prior to this feeling, were you  comfortable having physical contact  with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) Oh, yeah. (pause) But see, I've never really been  into sex that much, I mean, I like  it and everything, it just does't  freak me out, I wouldn't miss it,  you know? But anyway, lately we  haven't been doing anything at  all. Like I said, it's not that  I miss it, but I m curious the  way things kind of slacked off  all of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Cynthia are now having sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) Perhaps he senses your hesitance  at being touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) But see, he stopped before I got  that feeling, that's why it seems  weird to me. I mean, I'm sure he  wishes I would initiate things  once in awhile, and I would  except it never occurs to me, I'm  always thinking about something  else and then the few times that I  have felt like starting something  I was by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)  Did you do anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)  What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)  Did you masturbate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback)  God, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it you've never masturbated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly uncomfortable)  Well, I kind of tried once. It  just seemed stupid, I kept seeing  myself lying there and it seemed  stupid, and kind of, uh, I don't  know, and then I was wondering  if my dead grandfather could see  me doing this, and it just seemed  like a dumb thing to be doing when  we don't know what to do with all  that garbage, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it was recently that you tried  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhales, head down) Well, kind of recently, I guess.  But not too recently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really not up to having a guest  in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Cynthia are lying in bed, bathed in sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get back to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only get one today? Gee, how  exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John rolls over and begins to put his clothes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't let my lunch hour go on  too long. I've already skipped  one meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me this  passive/aggressive bullshit. If  you want to leave, leave. My life  doesn't stop when you walk out the  door, you know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just tell me how you really feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stands and begins putting on his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a friend coming in from  out of town, I'll probably be  spending some time with him the  next couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning we'll have to cool it for awhile, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent shrug from Cynthia. John is almost completely dr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd quit that bartending job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate the thought of guys hitting on you all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can handle it. Besides, the money  is good and some of the guys are  cute. And you are in no position  to be jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said I was jealous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'd like to try your  house sometime. The idea of doing  it in my sister's bed gives me  a perverse thrill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John thinks about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could tell everybody that  Ann's a lousy lay. Beautiful,  popular, Ann Bishop Millaney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be risky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I could just start  a rumor, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean doing it at my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid of getting caught?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be. Can I meet this  friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia, I don't think you want  to, I mean, you should see the  way he dresses. I really think  he's in a bad way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're intrigued?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Maybe he's the man I'm  looking for. Then I won't have  to fuck worried husbands all the  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John looks at her for a moment before heading for the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham has parked in the Millaney's driveway. He opens th trunk, revealing a Sony 8mm Video rig and a single black bag. He grabs the duffle bag and shuts the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham knocks at the door. He is stubbing out a cigarette his beaten tennis shoe when Ann answers the door. She is to hide her suprise at his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extends his hand)  Graham Dalton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I use your bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann withdraws her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, come in, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham moves inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann closes the door and motions Graham to the rear of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight back, first door on the  left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham heads for the bathroom. Ann heads for the phone. S dials John's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forman, Brent, and Millaney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Millaney, please. This is  his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham exits the bathroom. Ann quickly hangs up the phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: False alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham sits, his manner pleasantly animated. He gets his from inside his scuffed black leather jacket and looks ar for an ashtray. Ann swallows uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We...don't usually let people smoke  in the house. We have a patio if you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no problem. It can wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of silence. Graham looks at Ann directly. It is a challenging stare, he's just trying to ascertain what k of person she is. Ann, to her credit, somehow meets his g Something subtle passes between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at duffle bag)  Do you have other things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (pause) Oh, you mean to bring in! No. Yes,  I have some other things, no, I  don't need to bring them in. This  is all I need to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham smiles. He has an unusual face, a face that fluctu between remarkably handsome and just plain strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been on television?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Televison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)  Curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The central air-conditioning switches on. Ann smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham is an unusual name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it is. My mother  is a complete Anglophile, anything  British makes her drool like a  baby. She probably heard the name  in some movie. She's a prisoner  of public television now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you uncomfortable with my appearance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (downplaying) No, I think you look...fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Oh. Well, maybe I'm uncomfortable  with my appearance. I feel a little  out of place in these surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to take great pleasure in  that, being purposefully different,  rubbing people's noses in it.  Didn't you do that when you were  younger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks)  No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, I did. I was in a band  once, and the music was always  secondary to just flat out  offending as many people as  possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You play an instrument?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I was in charge of kind of  standing at the microphone and  reciting these really depressing  lyrics in a monotone. The whole  thing was really .... irrelevant.  How do you like being married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught slightly off guard) Oh, I like it. I like it very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it do you like? I'm  not being critical, I'd really  like to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.....well, the clichГ© about the security of it, that's really  true. We own a house, and I really  like that, you know? And I like  that John was just made junior  partner, so he has a steady job  and he's not some...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann looks at Graham and stops. He smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...free-lance. You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. So you feel security,  stability. Like things are going  to last awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, definitely. I mean, just this  past year has gone by like phew!  I hardly even knew it passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that if you shut  someone up in a room, and the only  clock he has reference to runs  two hours slow for every  twenty-four, that his body will  eventually adjust to that schedule?  Simply because the mind honestly  perceives that twenty-six hours  are twenty-four, the body follows. And then there are sections of time.  Your life can be broken down into  the sections of time that formed  your personality (if you have one).  For instance, when I was twelve, I had an eleven minute conversation  with my father that to this day  defines our relationship. Now,  I'm not saying that everything  happened in that specific section  of time, but the events of my  childhood involving my father led  up to, and then were crystallized  in, that eleven minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann is fascinated, if a bit overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Anyway, I think the mind is very  flexible as far as time is  concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like "time flies"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. I would say the fact that  you feel the first year of your  marriage has gone by quickly means  lots of things. Or could mean lots  of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has it been since you've  seen John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I was surprised that he  accepted when I asked if I could  stay here until I found a place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Didn't you know him well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew him very well. We were  extremely close until I dropped  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you drop out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, lots of reasons, most of them  boring. But, up until I dropped  out, John and I were...very much  alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's hard to believe. The two  of you seem so different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would imagine that we are, now.  I think I'm ready to use the  bathroom, finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham gets up and heads for the toilet. Ann watches him a bemused smile on her face. After she hears the door clo she can't resist the impulse to take a closer look at Gra bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE BATHROOM, Graham pokes around, looking through the medicine cabinet and sniffing towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)  Call the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, Ann and Graham are eating dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Graham) That's the first thing that ran  through my mind when I saw you.  I thought this is not the same  man that rode the unicycle naked  through the homecoming parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Graham)  You did that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody has a past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles at Graham) What do you think the Greeks would  make of that outfit you're wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bonfire, probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John takes a sip of Chivas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ann) This food is excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's not bad. Usually Ann  has some serious salt action going.  I keep telling her, you can always  add more if you want, but you can't  take it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ann) You have family here also?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, chewing)  Mother, father, sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister older or younger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Younger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John takes a large swig of Chivas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you close?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham sees Ann and John exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Am I prying again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were prying before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, this afternoon. I was grilling  Ann about your marriage this  afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Really. How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She held up very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ann) So I was asking about your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann's smile fades. John resumes eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we get along okay. She's just  very...she's an extrovert. I think  she's loud. She probably wouldn't  agree. Definitely wouldn't agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Graham) Are you going to see Elizabeth  while you re here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An almost imperceptible reaction by Graham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested) Who's Elizabeth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl Graham dated. Still lives  here, far as I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham eats in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham and I were talking about  apartments and I told him to check  the Garden District, there are  some nice little places there,  garage apartments and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Graham) Stay away from the Garden District.  Serious crime. I don't know what  kind of place you're looking for,  but there are a lot of studio-type  apartments available elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I didn't have to live  someplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)  What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham thinks a moment, then puts his keyring with its si key onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, see, right now I have this  one key, and I really like that.  Everything I own is in my car.  If I get an apartment, that's two  keys. If I get a job, maybe I  have to open and close once in  awhile, that's more keys. Or I  buy some stuff and I m worried  about getting ripped off, so I  get some locks, and that's more  keys. I just really like having  the one key. It's clean, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham looks at the keyring before returning it to his po

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of the car when you get  your apartment, then you'll still  have one key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like having the car, the car  is important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially if you want to leave  someplace in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or go someplace in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann takes her plate into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles at Graham)  Do you pay taxes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham also stands, empty plate in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I pay taxes? Of course I pay  taxes, only a liar doesn't pay  taxes, I'm not a liar. A liar is  the second lowest form of human  being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen)  What's the first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John smiles, thinking. Graham follows Ann into the kitche John shouts after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ann, why don't you go with  Graham to hunt for apartments?  Show him how the city has changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann looks at Graham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts back to John)  Okay, I will!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, sitting at the table and now toying with his keyrin nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone but Ann is asleep. She gets up from her bed and quietly into the guest bedroom where Graham is staying. S walks cautiously up to his bed to watch him as he sleeps. Moonlight caresses his face as he breathes peacefully. Ex he turns over slowly, his back to Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up his jacket from beside the bed and feels the surface. She brings the jacket to her nose, inhaling his  presence. She then sets the jacket down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Cynthia answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia. John. Meet me at my house  in exactly one hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are scum. I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham and Ann walk around the room, their footfalls heav the hardwood floors. MR. MILLER, the landlord, stands nea He looks fairly interested in Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty of room for two people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll just be me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Student?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (pause) You said three-fifty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus first and last month deposit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you lease month-to-month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for three-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about for five hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Miller looks at Ann, then back at Graham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia lets herself in. She looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offscreen) In here!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia walks to the bedroom, where John lies naked on th She smiles, kicking off her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia begins taking her clothes off. She places her dia stud earring in her jacket pocket, and then drops the jac on the floor. She moves onto the bed with John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) Maybe you'll understand this, because you know John, but he confuses me sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham and Ann are having lunch. Ann looks to have had a of wine. Graham drinks club soda with a twist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to explain. It's like... John treats everybody the same, you know? I mean, he acts just as excited about seeing somebody he hardly knows as he does when he sees me. And so I feel like, what's different about me, if I'm treated exactly the same as some acquaintance? If I don't like somebody, I don't act like I do. I guess that's why a lot of people think I'm a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. I mean, I'm not saying I know people think you're a bitch, I'm saying I know what you mean. And I don't even know that people think you're a bitch. Do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. Well, maybe you are. Really, I wouldn't pay much attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that I just don't feel a connection with very many people, so I don't waste time with people I don't feel one with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, right. I don't feel connected to many people, either. Other than John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tell you something personal? I feel like I can. It's something I couldn't tell John. Or wouldn't, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up to you. But I warn you, if you tell me something personal, I might do the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I think...I think sex is overrated. I think people place way too much importance on it. And I think that stuff about women wanting it just as bad is crap. I m not saying women don't want it, I just don't think they want it for the reason men think they do. (smiles) I'm getting confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand what I'm trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. I remember reading somewhere that men learn to love what they're attracted to, whereas women become more and more attracted to the person they love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! I think that's very true. Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham watches Ann take a sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what about kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids? What about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, actually, I do. But John doesn't. At least not right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, he just said he wants to wait. I quit asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's your personal thing? Are you really going to tell me something personal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as it's not...gross, you know? Like some scar or something. It has to be like mine, like something about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham takes a sip of club soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impotent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann looks at him closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impotent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let me put it this way: I cannot achieve an erection while in the presence of another person. So, for all practical purposes, I am impotent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann takes a large sip of wine. Graham lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhales) Not usually. I mean, honestly, I haven't known many guys that could think straight with an erection, so I feel I'm way ahead of the game as far as being clear-headed goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...are you self-conscious about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am self-conscious, but not in the same way that you are. You have got to be the most attractive self-conscious person I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say I'm self-conscious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've been watching you. I've watched you eat, I've watched you speak, I've watched the way you move, and I see somebody who is extremely conscious of being looked at. I think you really believe that people are looking at you all the time. And you know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are looking at you. Ann, you are truly breathtaking. I don't know if you understand how your appearance can affect people. Men want to possess you, women wish they looked like you. And those that don't or can't resent you. And the fact that you're a nice person just makes it worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) My therapist said that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah! No, I'm not. Actually, I used to be, but the therapist I had was really ineffectual in helping me deal with my problems. Of course, I lied to him constantly, so I guess I can't hold him totally responsible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't believe in therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in it for some people. I mean, for me it was silly, I was confused going in. So I just formed my own personal theory that you should never take advice from someone of the opposite sex that doesn't know you intimately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my therapist knows me intimately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) You had sex with you therapist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, see, I meant someone you've had sex with. That's part of the theory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me for asking, but how would you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Well, I wasn't always impotent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann takes another sip of wine and thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you said never take advice from someone that you don't know intimately, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basically, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia is leaving the house. She gives John a big kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) So since I've never had sex with you, by your own advice I shouldn't accept your advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) That's correct. (pause) Bit of a dilemma, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia is not wearing her diamond stud earring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know. The week started off okay, but then I was outside watering the plants, and I started feeling dizzy from the heat and that got me thinking about the Greenhouse Effect, so I went inside and turned on the air-conditioner full blast, and that made me feel a little better until I started thinking about radon leakage coming up through the floor, and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radon leakage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's this radioactive gas in the ground, and houses kind of act like magnets to pull it up, and--you've never heard of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the cumulative effect is not good, let me tell you. (pause) I knew I shouldn't have watered those plants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you confront John about the visitor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What visitor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The friend of John's that was staying at your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Graham. No, I didn't talk to him about that. Actually, that turned out to be pretty interesting. I expected Graham to be this...well, like John, you know? I mean, he said they had gone to school together, so I was expecting lots of stories about getting drunk and secret handshakes and stuff. But he turned out to be this...this kind of character, I mean, he's kind of arty but okay, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he still at your house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he left last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find him attractive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, like physically?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me rephrase. Were you attracted to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) I guess, but not because of the way he looked or anything. He's just so different, somebody new to have a conversation with. I'm just tired of talking to other couples about whether or not they're going to buy the station wagon, you know? It's just boring. I don't know, he was just different. And he's really on about truth a lot, being honest, and I like that, I felt comfortable around him. (pause) After he left I had a dream that he signed a lease to rent our guest room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over) So where's he from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann stands watching Cynthia get dressed for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He went to school here, then he was in New York for awhile, then Philadelphia, and then just kind of travelling around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be nice. So, what's he like, is he like John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at all. Actually, I don't think John likes him much anymore. He said he thought Graham had gotten strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he? Strange, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. Maybe if I just saw him on the street I'd have said that, but after talking to him...he's just kind of...I don't know, unusual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. So what's he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know what he looks like, is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, so you can go after him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Ann, get a life. I just asked what he looked like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, even if I decided to fuck his brains out, what business is that of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what. You say it just to irritate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say it because it's descriptive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he doesn't strike me as the kind of person that would go in for that sort of thing, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann, you always underestimate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wonder why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're afraid to put the two of us in the same room together. I think you're afraid he'll be undeniably drawn to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for God's sake. Really, Cynthia, really, I don't think he's your type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My type"? What is this bullshit? How would you know what "my type" is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a pretty good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann, you don't have a clue. Look, I don't even know why we're discussing this, I'll just call him myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll call him when he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not getting a phone, he doesn't like talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please. Okay,' so give me the Zen master's address, I'll think of a reason to stop by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk to him first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Just give me the address, you won't even have to be involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel right just giving you the address so that you can go over there and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...do whatever it is you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia laughs loudly. Ann, not happy, watches her dig th the jewelry box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lose something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That goddam diamond stud earring that cost me a fucking fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you getting Mom something for her birthday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'll get her a card or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A card? For her fiftieth birthday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think she deserves a little more than a card? I mean, the woman gave birth to you. It s her fiftieth birthday--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop? Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought it might--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ann, okay. How about this: you buy her something nice, and I'll pay for half. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now, if you'll pardon me, I have to go to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking maybe I shouldn't be in therapy anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brought this on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about it for awhile, and then I was talking to somebody who kind of put things in perspective for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I thought that's what I did. Who was it that you talked to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy Graham I told you about. He said taking advice from someone you don't know intimately was...well, he said a lot of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor exhales, thinking for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann, in life one has to be aware of hidden agendas. (pause) Did it occur to you that Graham may have his own reasons for not wanting you to be in therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible that Graham has hidden motives for disliking therapy and/or therapists. Perhaps he has problems of his own that he is unwilling to deal with, and he would like to see other people, you for instance, wallow in their situation just as he does. Do you think that's possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand that you are free to leave therapy at any time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you are under no obligation to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to leave therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel there is more progress to be made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you feel that way, because I feel that way, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't have hidden motives for feeling that way, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor laughs. Ann does not laugh with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a television monitor we see images originating from an Video deck. Graham sits naked in a sheet-covered chair fa the screen. He watches the tape, which is footage of hims interviewing a girl about her sexual preferences. The photography on the tape is handheld, relentless. As the questions get more detailed, Graham becomes more aroused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on Graham's door. He calmly shuts off th videotape player and stands, wrapping the sheet around hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham walks into the bedroom to put on some clothes. Ann the door and walks into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Ann. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in the middle of something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Nothing I can't finish later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks) I just wanted to see how the place looked furnished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Off) Not much to see, I'm afraid. I'm sort of cultivating a minimalist vibe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow I imagined books. I thought you would have like a whole lot of books and be reading all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do read a lot. But I check everything out of the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham picks up an Anais Nin diary and opens it to show A the library sleeve inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheaper that way. And cuts down on the clutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann walks to the table where the video gear is set up. Gr watches her closely. She looks into a large box of 8mm videotapes. On the side of each tape is a label. The labe look like this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so on. There are thirty or forty tapes, total.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Videotapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I can see that. What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham exhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a personal project I'm working on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of personal project?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just a personal project like anyone else's personal project. Mine's just a little more personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Donna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna. On this tape it says "Donna".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking) Donna was a girl I knew in Florida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went out with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann looks in the box again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come all these are girl's names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I enjoy interviewing women more than men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of these are interviews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we look at one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I promised each subject that no one would look at the tape except me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann looks at Graham for a long moment, then back at the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...what are these interviews about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The...interviews are about sex, Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About sex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about sex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything about sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what they've done, what they do, what they don't do, what they want to do but are afraid to ask for, what they won't do even if asked. Anything I can think of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just ask them questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they just answer them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly. Sometimes they do things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not to me, for me, for the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) I don't ...why...why do you do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry this came up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just...so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you want to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann nods and absently heads for the door. She gives Graha puzzled look before leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann is talking to Cynthia on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still shaken) I don't...he doesn't want you to come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean he doesn't want me to come over? Did you tell him about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I never got around to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because. Cynthia, look, John was right. Graham is strange. Very strange. You don't want to get involved with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened over there? Did he make a pass at you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's the story, what's this "strange" bullshit all of a sudden? Is he drowning puppies, or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's nothing like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what? Is he dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's not dangerous. Not physically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why'd you call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia gets out of the shower. The phone rings. She wrap herself in a towel and lifts the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia. John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not today. I've got other plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (pause) Well, when, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about inviting me over to dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham sits smoking a cigarette. There is a knock at his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia enters. Graham looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Cynthia Bishop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ann Millaney's sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The extrovert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) She must have been in a good mood when she said that. She usually calls me loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She called you that, too. May I ask why you re here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know why you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, like I said, Ann is my sister. Sisters talk. You can imagine the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I really can't. I find it healthy never to characterize people I don't know or conversations I haven't heard. I don't know what you and your sister discussed about me or anything else. Last time I saw Ann she left here very...confused, I would say. And upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Scrubbin that are already clean, vacuuming the same area of rug ov and over, etc. Suddenly, an object lodges itself in the s of the vacuum cleaner, making a loud noise. What happened to me? Have I been asleep? I vaguely remember the wedding, but a lot of it is just a blur...like I was watching from a distance. I can't believe him. Why didn't I trust my intuition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm vacuuming his goddam rug. His rug, that he paid to have put in his house. Nothing in that place belongs to me. I wanted to put some of my grandmother's furniture in it, but he wouldn't let me. So I m vacuuming his rug. That bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
